Description: Egyptian terracotta figure plaque of horseman. Horse is rearing above a shield. Horseman is wearing a cloak, but missing his head. Mould-made and solid figure plaque. Traces of red paint over a white coating. Dark red-brown Nile silt fabric with light brown surface. Abundant fine gold mica, quartz and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Relief plaque of a Macedonian cavalry rearing over a fallen foe. This subject and style is common in the 4th century BC, particularly in the early 4th century BC (Bayer-Niemeier 1988; pl. 91.4, no. 513). The fabric and technology used are identical to Late Period relief plaques. See also NA500 in Cambridge and also from Naukratis. Bayer-Niemeier, E. 1988. Liebieghaus Museum Alter Plastik. Bildwerke der Sammlung Kaufmann, 1. Griechisch-römische Terrakotten. Melsungen.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DC.228) (Phase 1)
Gutch 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis, D. The Terracottas (p. 95, nos 281-282)
